elements.content: Nanozymes are one of the ideal alternatives to natural enzymes for various applications. The rational design of nanozymes with improved catalytic activity stimulates increasing attention to address the low activity of current nanozymes. Here, we reported a general strategy to fabricate the Co-based homobimetallic hollow nanocages (HNCs) (C–CoM–HNC, M = Ni, Mn, Cu, and Zn) by ion-assistant solvothermal reaction and subsequent low-temperature calcination from metal–organic frameworks. The C–CoM–HNCs are featured with HNCs composed of interlaced nanosheets with homogeneous bimetallic oxide dispersion. The hierarchical structure and secondary metallic doping endow the C–CoM–HNC highly active sites. In particular, the Cu-doped C–CoCu–HNCs nanostructures exhibit superior performances over the other C–CoM–HNC as both the oxidase mimicking and peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activator. A sensitive bioassay for acetylcholinesterase (AChE) was established based on the excellent oxidase-like activity of C–CoCu–HNC, offering a linear detection range from 0.0001 to 1 mU/mL with an ultralow detection limit of 0.1 mU/L. As the PMS activator, the C–CoCu–HNC was applied for targeted organic pollutant (rhodamine B, RhB) degradation. A highly efficient RhB degradation was realized, along with good adaptability in a wide pH range and good reusability during the eight-cycle run. The results suggest that C–CoCu–HNC holds a practical potential for clinical diagnostics and pollution removal. Further density functional theory calculation reveals that Cu doping leads to a tighter connection and more negative adsorption energy for O2/PMS, as well as an upshifted d-band center in the C–CoCu–HNCs nanostructures. These changes facilitated the adsorption of O2/PMS on the C–CoCu–HNC surface for dissociation. This work not only offers a promising multifunctional nanozyme catalyst for clinical diagnostics and pollution removal but also gives some clues for the further development of novel nanozymes with high catalytic activities.

elements.content: Nanozymes are nanomaterials with intrinsic enzyme-like merits. They can surmount the shortcomings of natural enzymes, such as low stability, high cost, and difficult storage, serving as ideal alternatives to natural enzymes for a variety of applications. Basically, with the catalyzing reactions for enzyme-link substrate oxidation, nanozymes can be employed for quantitative determination of various biomolecules. Since the pioneering work reported by Yan’s group, thousands of nanozymes have been developed for various applications, ranging from analytical detection of cholesterol, glucose, lactate, ascorbic acid, dopamine, biothiols, circulation tumor cells, to therapeutic applications. Also, nanozymes can be applied for environmental remediation. For example, Jain et al. synthesized iron oxide nanorods with efficient peroxidase-mimicking activity for degradation of dyes. Wang et al. fabricated a bioinspired laccase-mimicking nanozyme for the degradation and detection of phenolic pollutants. Zhao et al. reported a heterogeneous single iron atom catalyst with high enzyme-like activity to degrade carcinogenic organic pollutants. Although substantial progress has been achieved in past few years, the moderate or even low catalytic activity is one of the tough challenges for further applications of nanozymes. The fabrication of nanozymes in the previous works was mostly performed via a trial-and-error strategy. There is lack of systematic studies to guide the exploitation of high-performance nanozymes. Additionally, restricted to conventional treatment, most of the reported nanozymes are mediocre to achieve sensitive signal transductions, which are far from satisfactory performance in practical applications. In this regard, the rational design of novel nanozymes with highly catalytic activity stimulates increasing attention but is challenging to address the low activity of current nanozymes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nanozymes are nanomaterials with intrinsic enzyme-like merits. They can surmount the shortcomings of natural enzymes, such as low stability, high cost, and difficult storage, serving as ideal alternatives to natural enzymes for a variety of applications. Basically, with the catalyzing reactions for enzyme-link substrate oxidation, nanozymes can be employed for quantitative determination of various biomolecules. Since the pioneering work reported by Yan's group, thousands of nanozymes have been developed for various applications, ranging from analytical detection of cholesterol, glucose, lactate, ascorbic acid, dopamine, biothiols, circulation tumor cells, to therapeutic applications. Also, nanozymes can be applied for environmental remediation. For example, Jain et al. synthesized iron oxide nanorods with efficient peroxidase-mimicking activity for degradation of dyes. Wang et al. fabricated a bioinspired laccase-mimicking nanozyme for the degradation and detection of phenolic pollutants. Zhao et al. reported a heterogeneous single iron atom catalyst with high enzyme-like activity to degrade carcinogenic organic pollutants. Although substantial progress has been achieved in past few years, the moderate or even low catalytic activity is one of the tough challenges for further applications of nanozymes. The fabrication of nanozymes in the previous works was mostly performed via a trial-and-error strategy. There is lack of systematic studies to guide the exploitation of high-performance nanozymes. Additionally, restricted to conventional treatment, most of the reported nanozymes are mediocre to achieve sensitive signal transductions, which are far from satisfactory performance in practical applications. In this regard, the rational design of novel nanozymes with highly catalytic activity stimulates increasing attention but is challenging to address the low activity of current nanozymes.

elements.content: Introducing secondary metal into monometallic counterpart is an effective way to modulate the reactivity of heterogeneous catalysts. The secondary-metal incorporation can provide new geometrically active sites for catalysts or change the electronic properties of the active sites by electron transfer between guest and host metals, resulting in a synergetic effect for higher catalytic activity. Proof-of-concept trials have been demonstrated by various bimetallic catalysts, including PdPt bimetallic alloy nanosponges, rhombic dodecahedral IrNi nanoframes, Cu-substituted cobalt oxides, and Fe-doped Ni2P nanosheets. In some cases, the synergistic effect can be even maximized via reasonable optimization of different components. Apart from the melioration of active sites, fine modifications of morphologies also play an important role in reactivity improvements. Hollow nanocage (HNC), one of the most intriguing structures, is appealing in catalysis because of its large surface area, huge void space, short interfacial transportation distance, and integrally exposed active sites. Hollow nanomaterials, such as hollow copper sulfide nanocubes, hollow Prussian blue, and hollow uranium oxide nanospheres, have been confirmed to possess excellent mimicking-enzyme catalytic activity. With these in mind, bimetallic nanozymes with hollow interior are expected to promise a great catalytic activity. However, no hollow bimetallic nanozymes have been reported up to now, probably because of the difficulty in delicately controllable morphology and composition. In our previous works, we have demonstrated the great potential of MOF-based materials as nanozymes. Considering the versatility of MOFs in morphology and composition, as well as its inherent talent to work as self-sacrificed template, it is a good candidate to fill this gap by properly processing the MOF precursors.

elements.content: Here, we reported a general strategy to prepare a series of Co-based homobimetallic HNCs (C–CoM–HNC, M = Ni, Mn, Cu, and Zn) derived from MOFs and demonstrated their use as multifunctional nanozymes for biosensing and organic pollutant degradation. As shown in , after the CoM-ZIFs (zeolitic imidazolate frameworks) were synthesized by self-assembly, an ion-assistant solvothermal reaction was carried out to modulate the coordination between metallic nodes and organic linkers, leading to shape evolution from solid polyhedra into HNCs. Then, low-temperature calcination was adopted to carbonize the intermediates to produce the C–CoM–HNC hybrids. In the strategy, not only the structure of MOF precursors has been changed under a controllable manner, but also the secondary metal ions can be introduced to form synergistic active sites with the inherent cobalt ions. By testing the oxidase-like activity and peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation capacity of C–CoM–HNCs, their promoting catalytic activities were verified. The potential of the optimal C–CoCu–HNC as the multifunctional nanozyme catalyst for the sensitive assay of AChE and efficient degradation of organic pollution RhB (rhodamine B) were investigated in detail. Furthermore, the density functional theory (DFT) calculation was conducted to get an insight into the theoretical origin of the improved catalytic activity. This work represents an avenue to design new nanozymes as multifunctional heterocatalysts for sensitive bioassay and efficient organic pollution degradation.

elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of a General Approach for C-CoM-HNC Synthesis

elements.content: illustrates the synthesis process of the C–CoM–HNC. First, the Co-ZIF and bimetallic CoM-ZIF were synthesized by the self-assembly of Co2+/M2+ and 2-methylimidazole (2-MIM) in methanol media through ultrasonic treatment. Scanning electron microscopy images (Figure S1) reveal that all of the Co-based ZIFs are well-defined rhombic dodecahedrons with uniform size distributions around 700–1000 nm. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the Co-based ZIFs are well consistent with the simulation of ZIF-67 (Figure S2). Taking the ZIFs as sacrificial templates, the Co–HNCs and CoM–HNC intermediates were prepared via an ion-assistant solvothermal reaction. From Figure S3b,c, the ZIFs with the rhombic dodecahedral structure become regular nanocages composed of interlaced ultrathin nanosheets, accompanied by a product color change from purple into yellowish brown (Figure S3a). In the XRD patterns (Figure S4), the original peaks of ZIFs disappear and emerging peaks at 10.4, 20.8, 33.9, 37.7, and 59.4° for cobalt nitrate hydroxide (PDF# 46-0605) can be observed. This is because during reaction process, M2+ and CH3OH affect the coordination between Co2+/M2+ and 2-MIM in ZIFs, driving its structural evolution and leading to the spontaneous phase transformation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

Characterization of Catalysts

  illustrates the synthesis process of the C-CoM-HNC. First, the Co-ZIF and bimetallic CoM-ZIF were synthesized by the self-assembly of Co2+/M2+ and 2-methylimidazole (2-MIM) in methanol media through ultrasonic treatment. Scanning electron microscopy images (Figure S1) reveal that all of the Co-based ZIFs are well-defined rhombic dodecahedrons with uniform size distributions around 700-1000 nm. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the Co-based ZIFs are well consistent with the simulation of ZIF-67 (Figure S2). Taking the ZIFs as sacrificial templates, the Co-HNCs and CoM-HNC intermediates were prepared via an ion-assistant solvothermal reaction. From Figure S3b,c, the ZIFs with the rhombic dodecahedral structure become regular nanocages composed of interlaced ultrathin nanosheets, accompanied by a product color change from purple into yellowish brown (Figure S3a). In the XRD patterns (Figure S4), the original peaks of ZIFs disappear and emerging peaks at 10.4, 20.8, 33.9, 37.7, and 59.4° for cobalt nitrate hydroxide (PDF# 46-0605) can be observed. This is because during reaction process, M2+ and CH3OH affect the coordination between Co2+/M2+ and 2-MIM in ZIFs, driving its structural evolution and leading to the spontaneous phase transformation.

elements.content: Via carbonization under the Ar atmosphere, the HNCs were converted into homometallic carbon hybrids, namely, the C–Co–HNCs or the C–CoM–HNCs. Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the Co–HNC exhibits a significant weight decrease from 180 °C (Figure S5). When the temperature exceeds 300 °C, this decrease trend becomes slow. The derivative thermogravimetry data exhibits an endothermic peak at ∼238 °C. The results suggest that Co–HNC starts its pyrolysis around 180 °C and after an evident phase transition, it is stable above 300 °C. In this work, all HNCs were annealed at 350 °C to ensure complete carbonization. The as-prepared C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs inherit the morphology of the parent HNCs (Figure S3c,d), in which the interlaced nanosheets act as the building blocks to form a three-dimensional hollow structure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of C–Co–HNC (Figure S6a–c) and C–CoCu–HNC (a–c) confirm this hierarchical structure as well. This intriguing structure is considered to be advantageous for the exposure of accessible active sites as well as the diffusion of substrates. With the further magnifications of the samples, we can clearly observe the ultrathin nanosheets in the edge of the HNCs and no aggregates exist over the nanosheets, indicating the carbon matrix confine the in situ formation of the active site during carbonization. In the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images (Figures S6d and d), both C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC present clear lattice fringe spacings of 0.244, 0.286, and 0.467 nm, indexed to the (311), (220), and (111) lattice planes of Co3O4, respectively. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns (Figures S6e and e) demonstrate consistent results with characteristic diffraction rings of Co3O4. Energy-dispersive spectrometry (EDS) elemental mapping images (Figures S6f and f) reveal that C, O, and Co­(Cu) are homogenously distributed within the samples. The results indicate that the cobalt nitrate hydroxide in HNCs have been converted into metallic oxides in C–HNCs, which are further verified by XRD and Raman spectra of C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs. As shown in a, all of the C–CoM–HNCs exhibit uniform diffraction peaks at 19.00, 31.30, 36.85, 38.55, 44.80, 59.35, and 65.25°, matching well with the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (511), and (440) planes of Co3O4 (PDF# 42-1467). b shows that all of the C–CoM–HNCs present five Raman peaks, corresponding to five Raman-active modes (A1g, Eg, and 3 F2g) of spinel Co3O4. No peak shift or additional peak is observed in the C–CoM–HNC compared to the pristine C–Co–HNC. These data consistencies suggest that the secondary metal is homogeneously distributed and the influence of the doped secondary metal on material lattice constants is unnoticeable. This is because the doping metals have similar ionic radius and electronegativity to Co.

elements.content: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to uncover the surface chemistry of C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC. From the survey spectra (a), additional peaks over 930–950 eV in C–CoCu–HNC (inset in a) confirm the successful doping of Cu. In the high-resolution Cu 2p spectrum of C–CoCu–HNC (b), a satellite peak is observed around 941.90 eV. Component peaks at 934.51 and 954.33 eV are the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks, respectively. The result proves the existence of Cu2+ in C–CoCu–HNC. The Auger electron spectroscopy of the Cu LMM spectrum (c) presents a single peak at 917.52 eV, further reaffirming Cu2+ characteristics of C–CoCu–HNC. In the high-resolution Co 2p spectra of C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC (d), spin–orbital splitting peaks for Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 are observed, along with the satellite peaks at 789.00 and 804.94 eV. By deconvolution, both Co 2p3/2 peak and Co 2p1/2 peak exhibit doublet peaks for Co3+ and Co2+. However, compared with those in the pristine C–Co–HNC, the corresponding peaks in C–CoCu–HNC slightly shift to low binding energy (Table S1), indicating that the Cu doping causes an electronic modulation of Co in the C–CoCu–HNC. In the high-resolution O 1s spectrum (e), three oxygen species are observed, namely, the lattice oxygen in metallic oxides (Ol, at 530.15 eV), surface oxygen vacancy (Ov, at 531.17 eV), and the chemisorbed water and/or carbonates (Oc, at 532.25 eV). Influenced by Cu doping, the binding energy of Ol in C–CoCu–HNC shift to a low value relative to pristine C–Co–HNC. Simultaneously, the Ol content decreased while Ov increased (Table S1). The oxygen vacancy plays an important role in most catalytic processes. Thus, the change of oxygen species in the C–CoCu–HNC is beneficial to its catalytic activity. The embedded table in f lists the element content in C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC from XPS. Interestingly, the contents of the total metal in two samples are almost the same, implying that Cu integrates into the material by substituting the Co sites in C–Co–HNC rather than simply attaching on its surface. The atomic ratio of Co to Cu in C–CoCu–HNC is calculated as 7.58, which is close to the data (7.69) by the atomic absorption spectrophotometry.

elements.content: The oxidase-like activities of the C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs were evaluated by incubating them with typical enzyme-linked chromogenic substrates, including 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), o-phenylenediamine (OPD), and 2,2′-azino-bis­(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS). As a–c shows, the C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs can directly catalyze the oxidation of different substrates to produce characteristic peaks without any additional oxidant, and the absorbance follows the order of C–Co–HNC < C–CoNi–HNC < C–CoZn–HNC < C–CoMn–HNC < C–CoCu–HNC. This result suggests that the doping of secondary metals promotes the oxidase-like activity of C–Co–HNC, and Cu brings a most significant promotion among the doping metals.
elements.clean_text:
Oxidase-Like Activity of the C-CoM-HNCs

The oxidase-like activities of the C-Co-HNC and C-CoM-HNCs were evaluated by incubating them with typical enzyme-linked chromogenic substrates, including 3,3',5,5'-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), o-phenylenediamine (OPD), and 2,2'-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS). As a-c shows, the C-Co-HNC and C-CoM-HNCs can directly catalyze the oxidation of different substrates to produce characteristic peaks without any additional oxidant, and the absorbance follows the order of C-Co-HNC < C-CoNi-HNC < C-CoZn-HNC < C-CoMn-HNC < C-CoCu-HNC. This result suggests that the doping of secondary metals promotes the oxidase-like activity of C-Co-HNC, and Cu brings a most significant promotion among the doping metals.

elements.content: (a–c) UV–vis spectra of TMB, ABTS, and OPD solutions after incubation with C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs. Insets show the photographs of corresponding solution after reaction (bottles from left to right involved with C–Co–HNC, C–CoNi–HNC, C–CoMn–HNC, C–CoCu–HNC, and C–CoZn–HNC, respectively). (d) Steady-state kinetic curve of C–CoCu–HNC. (e) Double-reciprocal plots of C–CoCu–HNC. (f) V max and K m comparison of C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs. Error bars in (d–f) show the standard deviation of three independent measurements.

Insets show the photographs of corresponding solution after reaction (bottles from left to right involved with C-Co-HNC, C-CoNi-HNC, C-CoMn-HNC, C-CoCu-HNC, and C-CoZn-HNC, respectively). elements.content: Choosing TMB as the model substrate, steady-state kinetic analysis of the C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs was carried out. The Michaelis–Menten constant (K m) and maximum initial velocity (V max) were calculated using Lineweaver–Burk plots (d–f and S7). In comparison with pristine C–Co–HNC and other C–CoM–HNCs, the C–CoCu–HNC exhibited a much superior catalytic performance with smallest K m and maximal V max. The K m (0.0741 mM) of C–CoCu–HNC was only one-fifth of that of the C–Co–HNC (0.375 mM), while its V max (2.56 × 10–8 M s–1) was 5.3 times that of the C–Co–HNC (0.483 × 10–8 M s–1). The result indicates that Cu doping can greatly improve the binding affinity and oxidase-like catalytic activity of the C–Co–HNC toward TMB. When comparing the kinetic parameters of the C–CuCo–HNC with other oxidase mimics (Table S2), its performance is still prominent. The excellent catalytic activity enables the C–CoCu–HNC to be used in many applications.

elements.content: To obtain the maximal activity of C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC, the effects of pH and temperature were tested. As shown in Figure S8a, both C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC displayed an optimal performance at pH 4.0. The C–Co–HNC exhibited stable performances at 25–60 °C, and C–CoCu–HNCs retained most catalytic activity (>80%) at 35–55 °C (Figure S8b). Also, the C–CoCu–HNCs exhibited over 96% of the initial oxidase-like activity after exposed to the air for over one week (Figure S9), indicating good storage stability.

elements.content: Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) is a primary cholinesterase in human body. It can specifically hydrolyze acetylcholine and some other choline esters to rapidly terminate nerve impulse transmission at cholinergic synapse, ensuring the normal transmission of nerve signals in body. Abnormal AChE activity is closely associated with neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease. In the past decades, great efforts have been made to develop suitable AChE inhibitors for symptomatic treatments. Therefore, reliably monitoring the AChE activity is of significant importance for both clinical diagnosis and pharmacodynamic evaluation.
elements.clean_text:
C-CoCu-HNC-Based Bioassay for Screening AChE Activity and Its Inhibitor

Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) is a primary cholinesterase in human body. It can specifically hydrolyze acetylcholine and some other choline esters to rapidly terminate nerve impulse transmission at cholinergic synapse, ensuring the normal transmission of nerve signals in body. Abnormal AChE activity is closely associated with neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease. In the past decades, great efforts have been made to develop suitable AChE inhibitors for symptomatic treatments. Therefore, reliably monitoring the AChE activity is of significant importance for both clinical diagnosis and pharmacodynamic evaluation.

elements.content: Based on the excellent oxidase-like activity of C–CoCu–HNC, a sensitive bioassay for screening AChE activity was established by coupling the AChE/acetylthiocholine (ATCh) cascade enzymatic reaction with the C–CoCu–HNC/TMB colorimetric system. As depicted in a, the C–CoCu–HNC can catalyze oxidation of colorless TMB into blue oxTMB by dissolved oxygen, with a characteristic absorption peak at 652 nm (a). AChE can hydrolyze choline substrate ATCh to produce thiocholine. The generated thiocholine, as a reductant, can reduce the oxTMB back to TMB, resulting in a decrease in absorbance at 652 nm (A 652). Using the absorbance change ΔA 652 (ΔA 652 = A 0 – A 652, here A 0 is the initial absorbance intensity) as the probing signal, colorimetric assay was proposed for screening AChE activity. b,c shows the effects of ATCh concentration and ATCh/AChE incubation time for this assay, respectively. In the absence of AChE, ATCh has negligible influence on A 652 of the C–CoCu–HNC/TMB system. After AChE was added, the oxidation of TMB was inhibited, and A 652 gradually decreased with a higher concentration of ATCh or a longer incubation time. To ensure a sensitive detection, 0.6 mM ATCh and 30 min incubation time were chosen in the following experiments. d displays absorption spectra of the C–CoCu–HNC/TMB system in the presence of 0.6 mM ATCh and different concentrations of AChE. The A 652 displays continuous decrease with increasing AChE concentration from 0.0001 to 5 mU/mL (e). A linear relationship between ΔA 652 and AChE concentration can be found in the range of 0.0001–1 mU/mL, with the regression equation of ΔA 652 = 0.5751 [AChE] + 0.0297 (r 2 = 0.9934, n = 14) (inset in e). The limit of detection was as low as 0.1 mU/L. This value is much lower than those of most previous strategies (Table S3), suggesting the ultrahigh sensitivity of this assay for AChE activity detection. The repeatability of the bioassay was evaluated by seven repeated measurements of 1 U/L AChE. The relative standard deviation was 1.4%, indicating good precision of the bioassay for AChE.

elements.content: To test the feasibility of the assay for practical application, we determined AChE activity in erythrocytes from five anticoagulant whole blood samples. The samples were diluted with ultrapure water to make the concentration of AChE located in the linear range for AChE and minimize background interference. The AChE activities measured by the proposed strategy showed acceptable agreement with Ellman’s method (Table S4, see the Supporting Information), as well as those previously reported ranges, indicating the great potential of the bioassay for routine clinical diagnostics.

elements.content: The AChE inhibitor screening trial was carried out to further demonstrate the applicability of the bioassay. Huperzine-A is a typical reversible AChE inhibitor, which has been used for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. In this work, it was chosen as the inhibitor model. As expected, when huperzine-A was introduced into the AChE/ATCh cascade system, the formation of thiolcholine was blocked, thus permitting the effective oxidation of TMB catalyzed by C–CuCo–HNC. Fixed the AChE concentration (1 mU/mL), the absorbance of the TMB/C–CuCo–HNC/ATCh system is enhanced with increasing concentration of huperzine-A. On the basis of the plot of inhibition efficiency (%) versus the concentration of huperzine-A (f), the corresponding IC50 value (the inhibitor concentration required for 50% inhibition of the enzyme activity) was estimated to be 58.82 nM. This value is close to that of the previous report, revealing that the colorimetric array is reliable.

elements.content: RhB is a xanthene dye and widely used as a colorant in textiles and food stuffs. However, the confirmed biological toxicity, sustained emission, and environmental persistence enable RhB to be a highly focused organic pollutant. Various techniques have been developed over past decades for RhB removal, and the advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) was recognized as one of the most powerful techniques. Herein, we studied the potential of C–CoM–HNCs as the PMS activator for RhB degradation.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Performance of C-CoCu-HNC for RhB Degradation

RhB is a xanthene dye and widely used as a colorant in textiles and food stuffs. However, the confirmed biological toxicity, sustained emission, and environmental persistence enable RhB to be a highly focused organic pollutant. Various techniques have been developed over past decades for RhB removal, and the advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) was recognized as one of the most powerful techniques. Herein, we studied the potential of C-CoM-HNCs as the PMS activator for RhB degradation.

elements.content: a shows the catalytic performance dependence of different C–CoM–HNCs catalysts on reaction time. In accordance with the result of oxidase-like activity above, the C–CoCu–HNCs exhibit a prominent catalytic performance with faster degradation dynamics and higher degradation efficiency than the other C–CoM–HNCs catalysts (b). In the control test (c,d), negligible RhB degradation was observed in the absence of PMS and C–CoCu–HNCs. In the RhB/C–CoCu–HNCs system and RhB/PMS system, the degradation efficiencies of RhB were 10.48 and 26.45% after 60 min reaction, suggesting partial RhB removal by adsorption or direct catalytic degradation by PMS. When both the C–CoCu–HNCs and PMS were introduced, the concentration of RhB was significantly decreased after 30 min reaction. The degradation efficiency reached 93.41% after 60 min reaction, confirming the excellent PMS activation capacity of C–CoCu–HNC for RhB degradation.

elements.content: e,f displays the RhB degradation in the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system under different pH. In a wide pH range from 4 to 9, the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system maintained a high RhB degradation efficiency of over 90%. g,h presents the effect of PMS concentration on RhB degradation. In general, the higher the concentration of PMS, the faster the RhB degradation. When 0.15 g/L PMS was used, over 95% RhB degradation efficiency was achieved within 15 min. Adopting pseudo-first-order model to fit the experimental data, linear relationships can be found between ln­(C/C 0) and time. Table S5 summarizes the corresponding kinetic parameters. When PMS concentration was increased from 0.01 to 0.15 g/L, the apparent kinetic constant (k app) accordingly increased from 0.02 to 0.257 min–1. This value is comparable to or higher than most k app in previous reports (Table S6). Taking the catalyst concentration into consideration, the mass-normalized rate constants (k nor) were calculated. It is clear that the k nor of C–CoCu–HNC is much higher than that of other catalysts. For example, it is 12.6 times that of Co3O4, 54.3 times that of CoFe2O4, and 575.1 times that of CuBi2O4. The result demonstrates that the C–CoCu–HNC can efficiently activate PMS for organic pollution degradation with less catalyst loading.

elements.content: To explore the reusability of the catalyst, we recovered the C–CoCu–HNC from reaction solution by filtration, washing with water, and drying. Then, the recovered C–CoCu–HNC catalyst was reused to degrade RhB. As shown in Figure S10, the degradation efficiency of RhB in the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system suffered from some loss during the successive cycle runs, but it still maintained high degradation efficiency (>90%) even after eight runs. This result verified the good reusability of C–CoCu–HNC.

elements.content: To identify the dominant active radicals in the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system, quenching tests were conducted. Methanol has a high rate constant for both SO4 •– (k = 2.5 × 107 M–1 s–1) and •OH (k = 9.7 × 108 M–1 s–1); tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) has a higher rate constant for •OH (k = 3.8–7.6 × 108 M–1 s–1) and a much lower constant for SO4 •– (k = 4 × 107–9.1 × 107 M–1 s–1). Therefore, methanol can be used as scavenger for both radicals of SO4 •– and •OH, and TBA as a scavenger for •OH in the PMS-based AOPs. As shown in Figure S11, when TBA was introduced into the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system, RhB degradation efficiency decreased from 99.7 to 87.9% after 20 min reaction. The k app decreased from 0.235 to 0.108 min–1. When methanol was introduced, the RhB degradation efficiency and k app decreased to 65.4% and 0.053 min–1, respectively. These results indicated that both SO4 •– and •OH radicals were involved in the PMS activation process. Thus, we can deduce the PMS activation process by C–CoCu–HNC as follows ≡Co ( II ) + HS O 5 − → ≡Co ( III ) + S O 4 • − + O H − ≡Co ( III ) + HS O 5 − → ≡Co ( II ) + S O 5 • − + H + ≡Cu ( II ) − O − H + HS O 5 − → ≡Cu ( II ) − ( HO ) OS O 3 − + O H − ≡Cu ( II ) − ( HO ) OS O 3 − → ≡Cu ( III ) − O − H + S O 4 • − ≡Cu ( III ) − O − H + HS O 5 − → ≡Cu ( II ) − O • OS O 3 − + H 2 O 2 ≡Cu ( II ) − O • OS O 3 − + 2 H 2 O → 2 ≡Cu ( II ) − O − H + O 2 + 2 S O 4 • − + 2 H + S O 4 • − + H 2 O → S O 4 2 − + O • H + H + S O 4 • − / • OH + RhB → intermediates + C O 2

elements.content: The DFT calculations were carried out to gain a better insight into the origin of the improved catalytic activity of the C–CoCu–HNC compared with the C–Co–HNC. The computational details were provided in the Supporting Information. According to the characterization results, the mainly active sites in the C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC are metal oxides. We conducted the calculations with (111) metal lattice surfaces. shows the relaxed atomic structures of O2/PMS molecule adsorption on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4. displays the detail configurations from the top view and side view. After configuration optimization, the O2 chemically connects to the Co3O4 surface with one of the terminal oxygen bonding with Co. When adsorbed on CuCo2O4, both the two oxygen atoms in O2 bond to Co and Cu on the surface. This tighter connection between O2 and CuCo2O4 facilitates electron transfer from the Co/Cu to the antibonding π* orbital of O2, weakening the O–O bond in O2. Measuring the O–O distances (l O–O) of absorbed O2, both the l O–O on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 are elongated compared to free O2 (1.23 Å). The CuCo2O4 offers a longer l O–O (Table S7), suggesting that CuCo2O4 is more favorable to dissociate O2 to produce O adatoms and can subsequently snatch hydrogen from the surrounding substrate to complete the substrate oxidation. The adsorption energy (E ads) is a convenient descriptor to estimate the relative catalytic activity because of the good correlation between E ads and activation energies for small-molecule superficial reactions. In this work, the more negative value of E ads(O2) in CuCo2O4 explains its higher catalytic reactivity for O2 and better oxidase-like activity. To compare the PMS activation capacity, the optimized absorption atomic configurations of PMS on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 were also studied. As shown in and , PMS tends to lie above the surface of Co3O4 by physisorption. No chemical bond forms in this process. However, PMS can chemically adsorb on CuCo2O4 by binding the oxygen in −OH group with Co and single-bond oxygen in the −SO4 group with Cu, respectively. Table S7 lists the E ads of PMS on catalysts, corresponding l O–O of SO4–OH and electron transfer (Q e) from catalysts to PMS, respectively. As expected, CuCo2O4 shows more negative E ads and Q e (Figure S12), as well as longer l O–O compared to Co3O4. This implies that the CuCo2O4 has a stronger adsorption and electron-donating capability toward PMS, accelerating the bond breaking between −OH and −SO4 to form active intermediate SO4 •–. The theoretical result is consistent with the experimental finding that CuCo2O4 possesses a much high PMS activation capacity compared to Co3O4.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

The DFT calculations were carried out to gain a better insight into the origin of the improved catalytic activity of the C-CoCu-HNC compared with the C-Co-HNC. The computational details were provided in the Supporting Information. According to the characterization results, the mainly active sites in the C-Co-HNC and C-CoCu-HNC are metal oxides. We conducted the calculations with (111) metal lattice surfaces.  shows the relaxed atomic structures of O2/PMS molecule adsorption on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4.  displays the detail configurations from the top view and side view. After configuration optimization, the O2 chemically connects to the Co3O4 surface with one of the terminal oxygen bonding with Co. When adsorbed on CuCo2O4, both the two oxygen atoms in O2 bond to Co and Cu on the surface. This tighter connection between O2 and CuCo2O4 facilitates electron transfer from the Co/Cu to the antibonding π* orbital of O2, weakening the O-O bond in O2. Measuring the O-O distances (l O-O) of absorbed O2, both the l O-O on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 are elongated compared to free O2 (1.23 Å). The CuCo2O4 offers a longer l O-O (Table S7), suggesting that CuCo2O4 is more favorable to dissociate O2 to produce O adatoms and can subsequently snatch hydrogen from the surrounding substrate to complete the substrate oxidation. The adsorption energy (E ads) is a convenient descriptor to estimate the relative catalytic activity because of the good correlation between E ads and activation energies for small-molecule superficial reactions. In this work, the more negative value of E ads(O2) in CuCo2O4 explains its higher catalytic reactivity for O2 and better oxidase-like activity. To compare the PMS activation capacity, the optimized absorption atomic configurations of PMS on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 were also studied. As shown in  and , PMS tends to lie above the surface of Co3O4 by physisorption. No chemical bond forms in this process. However, PMS can chemically adsorb on CuCo2O4 by binding the oxygen in -OH group with Co and single-bond oxygen in the -SO4 group with Cu, respectively. Table S7 lists the E ads of PMS on catalysts, corresponding l O-O of SO4-OH and electron transfer (Q e) from catalysts to PMS, respectively. As expected, CuCo2O4 shows more negative E ads and Q e (Figure S12), as well as longer l O-O compared to Co3O4. This implies that the CuCo2O4 has a stronger adsorption and electron-donating capability toward PMS, accelerating the bond breaking between -OH and -SO4 to form active intermediate SO4 ⋅-. The theoretical result is consistent with the experimental finding that CuCo2O4 possesses a much high PMS activation capacity compared to Co3O4.

elements.content: To better rationalize the catalytic reactivity, d-band centers of Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 were also estimated. The change in the energy center of the valence d-band density of states at the surface sites is correlated with their ability to form chemisorption bonds, which can be used to predict the catalytic reactivity of materials. As seen in Figure S13, the d-band center (εd) of Co3O4 is slightly up shift from −1.25 to −1.15 eV upon Cu introduction. This suggests that Cu introduction can withdraw the charge of Co, making the antibonding states of Co empty, leading to increase in the adsorption energy of O2/PMS and to facilitate the adsorption of O2/PMS on the catalyst surface for dissociation.

elements.content: In conclusion, we successfully developed an ion-assistant solvothermal reaction combined with a low-temperature-mediated calcination strategy to synthesize the homobimetallic C–CoM–HNCs (M = Ni, Mn, Cu, and Zn) derived from MOFs. Compared with monometallic counterparts (C–Co–HNC), the bimetallic C–CoM–HNCs exhibited improved catalytic activities when working as an oxidase mimicking and PMS activator. The C–CoCu–HNC displays highest catalytic activity among four doped catalysts. The XPS characterization indicates that the Cu doping causes an increase in the surface oxygen vacancy of the C–Co–HNC. The high activity of the C–CoCu–HNC catalyst is further understood by control experiments and detailed DFT calculations. The excellent catalytic activity enables the C–CoCu–HNC to be used in many applications for screening AChE activity and its inhibitor by coupling with the AChE/ATCh cascade enzymatic reaction and for degrading RhB dye by efficiently activating PMS to produce SO4 •–. More importantly, the C–CoCu–HNC nanozyme exhibits ultrahigh sensitivity for detecting AChE activity and also displays high efficiency and good repeatability for RhB degradation. The success of this work offers a general strategy to construct the metal–organic framework-based nanozyme catalysts for potential applications in clinical diagnostics and pollution removal.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we successfully developed an ion-assistant solvothermal reaction combined with a low-temperature-mediated calcination strategy to synthesize the homobimetallic C-CoM-HNCs (M = Ni, Mn, Cu, and Zn) derived from MOFs. Compared with monometallic counterparts (C-Co-HNC), the bimetallic C-CoM-HNCs exhibited improved catalytic activities when working as an oxidase mimicking and PMS activator. The C-CoCu-HNC displays highest catalytic activity among four doped catalysts. The XPS characterization indicates that the Cu doping causes an increase in the surface oxygen vacancy of the C-Co-HNC. The high activity of the C-CoCu-HNC catalyst is further understood by control experiments and detailed DFT calculations. The excellent catalytic activity enables the C-CoCu-HNC to be used in many applications for screening AChE activity and its inhibitor by coupling with the AChE/ATCh cascade enzymatic reaction and for degrading RhB dye by efficiently activating PMS to produce SO4 ⋅-. More importantly, the C-CoCu-HNC nanozyme exhibits ultrahigh sensitivity for detecting AChE activity and also displays high efficiency and good repeatability for RhB degradation. The success of this work offers a general strategy to construct the metal-organic framework-based nanozyme catalysts for potential applications in clinical diagnostics and pollution removal.

cln_elements.content:
Choosing TMB as the model substrate, steady-state kinetic analysis of the C–Co–HNC and C–CoM–HNCs was carried out. The Michaelis–Menten constant (K m) and maximum initial velocity (V max) were calculated using Lineweaver–Burk plots (d–f and S7). In comparison with pristine C–Co–HNC and other C–CoM–HNCs, the C–CoCu–HNC exhibited a much superior catalytic performance with smallest K m and maximal V max. The K m (0.0741 mM) of C–CoCu–HNC was only one-fifth of that of the C–Co–HNC (0.375 mM), while its V max (2.56 × 10–8 M s–1) was 5.3 times that of the C–Co–HNC (0.483 × 10–8 M s–1). The result indicates that Cu doping can greatly improve the binding affinity and oxidase-like catalytic activity of the C–Co–HNC toward TMB. When comparing the kinetic parameters of the C–CuCo–HNC with other oxidase mimics (Table S2), its performance is still prominent. The excellent catalytic activity enables the C–CoCu–HNC to be used in many applications.

To obtain the maximal activity of C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC, the effects of pH and temperature were tested. As shown in Figure S8a, both C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC displayed an optimal performance at pH 4.0. The C–Co–HNC exhibited stable performances at 25–60 °C, and C–CoCu–HNCs retained most catalytic activity (>80%) at 35–55 °C (Figure S8b). Also, the C–CoCu–HNCs exhibited over 96% of the initial oxidase-like activity after exposed to the air for over one week (Figure S9), indicating good storage stability.

Based on the excellent oxidase-like activity of C–CoCu–HNC, a sensitive bioassay for screening AChE activity was established by coupling the AChE/acetylthiocholine (ATCh) cascade enzymatic reaction with the C–CoCu–HNC/TMB colorimetric system. As depicted in a, the C–CoCu–HNC can catalyze oxidation of colorless TMB into blue oxTMB by dissolved oxygen, with a characteristic absorption peak at 652 nm (a). AChE can hydrolyze choline substrate ATCh to produce thiocholine. The generated thiocholine, as a reductant, can reduce the oxTMB back to TMB, resulting in a decrease in absorbance at 652 nm (A 652). Using the absorbance change ΔA 652 (ΔA 652 = A 0 – A 652, here A 0 is the initial absorbance intensity) as the probing signal, colorimetric assay was proposed for screening AChE activity. b,c shows the effects of ATCh concentration and ATCh/AChE incubation time for this assay, respectively. In the absence of AChE, ATCh has negligible influence on A 652 of the C–CoCu–HNC/TMB system. After AChE was added, the oxidation of TMB was inhibited, and A 652 gradually decreased with a higher concentration of ATCh or a longer incubation time. To ensure a sensitive detection, 0.6 mM ATCh and 30 min incubation time were chosen in the following experiments. d displays absorption spectra of the C–CoCu–HNC/TMB system in the presence of 0.6 mM ATCh and different concentrations of AChE. The A 652 displays continuous decrease with increasing AChE concentration from 0.0001 to 5 mU/mL (e). A linear relationship between ΔA 652 and AChE concentration can be found in the range of 0.0001–1 mU/mL, with the regression equation of ΔA 652 = 0.5751 [AChE] + 0.0297 (r 2 = 0.9934, n = 14) (inset in e). The limit of detection was as low as 0.1 mU/L. This value is much lower than those of most previous strategies (Table S3), suggesting the ultrahigh sensitivity of this assay for AChE activity detection. The repeatability of the bioassay was evaluated by seven repeated measurements of 1 U/L AChE. The relative standard deviation was 1.4%, indicating good precision of the bioassay for AChE.

e,f displays the RhB degradation in the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system under different pH. In a wide pH range from 4 to 9, the C–CoCu–HNC/PMS system maintained a high RhB degradation efficiency of over 90%. g,h presents the effect of PMS concentration on RhB degradation. In general, the higher the concentration of PMS, the faster the RhB degradation. When 0.15 g/L PMS was used, over 95% RhB degradation efficiency was achieved within 15 min. Adopting pseudo-first-order model to fit the experimental data, linear relationships can be found between ln­(C/C 0) and time. Table S5 summarizes the corresponding kinetic parameters. When PMS concentration was increased from 0.01 to 0.15 g/L, the apparent kinetic constant (k app) accordingly increased from 0.02 to 0.257 min–1. This value is comparable to or higher than most k app in previous reports (Table S6). Taking the catalyst concentration into consideration, the mass-normalized rate constants (k nor) were calculated. It is clear that the k nor of C–CoCu–HNC is much higher than that of other catalysts. For example, it is 12.6 times that of Co3O4, 54.3 times that of CoFe2O4, and 575.1 times that of CuBi2O4. The result demonstrates that the C–CoCu–HNC can efficiently activate PMS for organic pollution degradation with less catalyst loading.

DFT Calculations

The DFT calculations were carried out to gain a better insight into the origin of the improved catalytic activity of the C–CoCu–HNC compared with the C–Co–HNC. The computational details were provided in the Supporting Information. According to the characterization results, the mainly active sites in the C–Co–HNC and C–CoCu–HNC are metal oxides. We conducted the calculations with (111) metal lattice surfaces. shows the relaxed atomic structures of O2/PMS molecule adsorption on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4. displays the detail configurations from the top view and side view. After configuration optimization, the O2 chemically connects to the Co3O4 surface with one of the terminal oxygen bonding with Co. When adsorbed on CuCo2O4, both the two oxygen atoms in O2 bond to Co and Cu on the surface. Measuring the O–O distances (l O–O) of absorbed O2, both the l O–O on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 are elongated compared to free O2 (1.23 Å). The CuCo2O4 offers a longer l O–O (Table S7), suggesting that CuCo2O4 is more favorable to dissociate O2 to produce O adatoms and can subsequently snatch hydrogen from the surrounding substrate to complete the substrate oxidation. The adsorption energy (E ads) is a convenient descriptor to estimate the relative catalytic activity because of the good correlation between E ads and activation energies for small-molecule superficial reactions. In this work, the more negative value of E ads(O2) in CuCo2O4 explains its higher catalytic reactivity for O2 and better oxidase-like activity. To compare the PMS activation capacity, the optimized absorption atomic configurations of PMS on Co3O4 and CuCo2O4 were also studied. As shown in and , PMS tends to lie above the surface of Co3O4 by physisorption. No chemical bond forms in this process. However, PMS can chemically adsorb on CuCo2O4 by binding the oxygen in −OH group with Co and single-bond oxygen in the −SO4 group with Cu, respectively. Table S7 lists the E ads of PMS on catalysts, corresponding l O–O of SO4–OH and electron transfer (Q e) from catalysts to PMS, respectively. As expected, CuCo2O4 shows more negative E ads and Q e (Figure S12), as well as longer l O–O compared to Co3O4. This implies that the CuCo2O4 has a stronger adsorption and electron-donating capability toward PMS, accelerating the bond breaking between −OH and −SO4 to form active intermediate SO4 •–. The theoretical result is consistent with the experimental finding that CuCo2O4 possesses a much high PMS activation capacity compared to Co3O4.
